Such rigid rules make no allowances for special circumstances, and basically say "I don't respect you one bit".
 Also, searching your child's room at random is wrong. You think that will build trust? You can't do that when they leave home, and it again shows an attitude of zero respect for your child.

In high school, it prepares them for the discipline of studying necessary for college. Kids that never develop good study habits are at a distinct disadvantage when they get to college. I know from experience.

I think homework is worthwhile, but it should be strictly time limited. Kids, like anyone else, need to have a strict boundary between work and leisure time. It's not going to do anyone any good to spend all day in school then spend 5 hours doing homework. If anything school days should be longer and independent study time built in to the timetable. This also has the advantage of partly solving childcare issues between the end of school and when parents finish work.

 I can't relate the negatives to group size. One of my smallest groups only has 6 kids. There is this one kid, Nick, who cannot talk without shouting and he cannot shut-up. He is disruptive. Class clown.emoticon_xclown He's a good boy. The kids all like him because they think he's funny. I like him too. Heck, I like 'em all. But this one kid cannot stand anyone else leading a conversation or getting attention. He will jump up, scream something funny, cut them off, out shout them and veer the attention to himself. (A future Bill O'Reilly perhaps.) My work is extremely hard when he is in the room and I haven't the heart to send him away. He already has enough problems. I am able to calm him when I address him very sternly. He respects me and he that knows I like him, so he does respond to command. For about a minute.
 
 My buddy, BJ, from Chicago is an elementry PE teacher. (It's not recess anymore.) He works with inner-city kids too. He is a laid back, guitar playing, white-rasta type, and one tall drink of water. I'll bet this guy is almost seven feet tall. He really loves his job and he genuinely loves each kid in that school as if they were all his very own. Unbelievable person. I can't say enough of how blessed the school district is to have him. His kids gather around him like the leaves around a tree. His kids are so sweet. It doesn't bother them at all that he is white. They are about in the 7-9 year old bracket. They LOVE to learn. BJ leaves to work smiling and he comes home from work smiling. I've never seen him not smiling. Great teacher too. Smart as a whip.
 
 Then there's poor Kimberly. Kimberly is a cute little blonde, second year teacher. Her class size is about 24 kids or so. Mostly inner-city kids as well. She leaves her room in tears almost everyday. I have personally witnessed her being called "white b**ch" (and worse) as well as many other select racial slurs and profane nouns by kids in the school. Her kids are only 12-13 years old. They are always bickering, screaming, insulting and very often fighting with each other. Almost everyday one of the little boys grabs one of the little girls breast, butt and beyond, or exposes himself. Outta control. She hasn't the time to teach, regardless of the curriculum. All she has time to do is scream and pull kids apart. Ironically, these kids are the same sweet kids that BJ had two or three years before. What happened to them?
 
 My point being, it only takes one or two kids to disrupt the learning of an entire class. Regardless of it's size. I think the problems in the classroom are carry-overs from the defiency of the parenting. It starts at home. I can see that from a Monday to a Tuesday. I'll be working with one group from the Northside and it's pure mayhem and chaos. The next day, I'll hit another district and the kids are respectful and orderly. They're only 5 miles apart.

 OK, I can live with removing the "Period". :) 
 But, as you point out above, it isn't the size of the class that's the root cause of problems, it's the behavior of a few individuals. A disruptive student in a class of 50 has the same effect as a disruptive student in a class of 5. 
 The disruptive student needs to be addressed, not class size, but you don't see teachers pushing for better procedures to handle disruptive students as much as you see them pushing for reduced class size. The reason is economic. In most unionized teacher contracts, class size is specified. If a district needs to exceed that arbitrary limit (and it is arbitrary), the teacher automatically gets a premium for the additional students. It's built into the contracts.

 Not on the national front you don't. That is to say, class size is always a plank in their program come negotiation time. Class reduction will cost a lot more to the district than giving the teachers raises and benefits will and it's a good bargaining tool I suppose. I don't know a single teacher willing to take a pay reduction directly proportional to her class reduction. They hope, in my opinion, to compromise at the bargaining table to accept the deal that "If you can't reduce my class sizes, (knowing they can't) I suppose I will accept a pay raise in-lieu of that." Fine, the teacher walks away satisfied, but the kids still don't learn. But in the defense of the teachers, they are sorely underpaid for the job they do so I do not begrudge them for trying to squeeze a nickel out of the system. They are facing cut-backs as never seen before. But they are dedicated. Many purchase classroom supplies from their own pocket and spend many extra hours at work. I do not question the dedication of about 80% of the teachers I work around.
 
 As as for addressing the problem of the kid. It's frustrating. Some kids get sent to the office to sit in a chair for an hour for offences that would cause another student, in another district, to be expelled for an entire year. Sending kids home from school is no longer a punishment to some kids but a privelege. To many parents just don't care. They scream for a minute and then go back and lay on the couch to watch TV. The teachers feel their hands are tied all to often. It's day in day out attempts to dicipline to no avail. Does it surprise anyone that they are unabale to teach? And that's sad for the kids that are behaved and there to learn.

I think class sizes are important (and you can't blame a US teacher union I've never heard of for this). It's blindingly obvious that it is easier to meet the needs of every child in a class of 5 than a class of 50. Some pupils require individual attention, at least to begin with, while others may be content to work alone. When I was at school we had classes set by ability, the highest ability groups had larger classes (~33) while the lower abiltiy groups were smaller (~12). I do think it makes a difference, not least because if you have a smaller class, a disruptive child has fewer people to bounce off, and a smaller audience to play up to.

Teachers here are the highest paid in the country (when adjusted for cost of living), so all I see are new cars out in the parking lots. In my district, the average teacher salary for the district is over $60k (last time I knew the details was late 90's) for 9 months work (182 days). As for their education, I would invite you to read Thomas Sowell's "Inside American Education". Using data from colleges and universities across the country, he compiled statistics on teaching vs other college curriculum and found that the lowest scoring students on entrance ACT and SAT tests went into teaching...but that's a topic for another thread.
That's a lotta money. The teachers I know here eat well and pay their bills but that's about it. No fancy cars or houses. Yet, they go in everyday and give their all.

 I'm guessing that you never ran for a seat on a large school board in which your opponent's sole campaign financier was the local teacher union? I did.
 My biggest "mistake" was proposing that teachers be held accountable for their students' performance just as managers in a business are responsible for their employees' performance. You'd have thought that I was the anti-christ after suggesting that. My opponent's campaign was run by the ex-president of the teacher union and they even had the gaul to solicit campaign funds during classtime and had students filling out postcards for my opponent. On the day of the election, they manned the phones at the union headquarters and urged people to vote for my opponent. How do I know that? Caller ID showed where the calls originated. I, also, did my homework and studied the teacher union contracts as well as the district's financials. I learned all about class size premiums, longevity bonuses, coaching pay, retirement padding, etc., At the time, we were paying over $8k/year/student. (This was 1995.)
 So, you see, my opinions of teacher unions and their inner workings were forged by baptism under fire, not by anyone else's talking points. emoticon_angry

I can see why you may be jaded going by your experiences JP. Mine are from a different perspective though. When I see my teacher acquaintances, and their modest living conditions (especially the young ones) I have to wonder how bad it would be for them without their union.

Popping my two cents in on this discussion. Mother of 4 and two are in college. We still have a 17 year old and an 11 year old at home. Sooooooooooo been there done that and none of our girls were juvenile delinquents that failed at school and no we didn't have to keep them on a short leash. 
 
 What works? Don't stop getting to know your child's school environment once they leave the elementary years. Meet the teachers, know the school policies and education agenda, and never be an absentee parent on the campus. Also don't assume that little Susie or Johnny, the best friends, are going to stay sweet and nice all through the growing up years. Stay in tune with your child's friends during the entire educational process. The biggest thing is respect your child's mind. No one wants to fail and everyone needs positive pushes. 
 
 OH, the biggest one yet, learn to listen when you ask," anything I need to know?" Your job isn't over just because you got the question out.

My wife and I always stayed active in our kids' grammar and HS years. There is no 100% solid formula for raising them properly as there are way too many factors involved. On class size.
 
 It depends on the subject, the lesson style and the people in the class.
 
 If it's a lecture style lesson you can have large classes and just send out all disruptive pupils. Being a lecture, they should easily be able to catch up on anything they miss and tend to learn quickly that messing around isn't good. Other classes where discussion takes place (for me, primarily English and Classics), class sizes need to be small (5-15) so that everyone can contribute. There's fairly little writing involved and it's mainly talking.
 
 I think disruptive pupils should just be sent out. I don't mind chit-chat during a class, everyone does it, but going out of your way to irritate the teacher and everyone else really isn't acceptable.
 
 -Wez

If teachers in the US are anything like those in the UK, they will work far more than 182 days a year, and probably work more than 12 hours on each of them, due to marking, planning etc. Sure there are some bad apples, but (to mix metaphors) I smell more sour grapes here than anything else.

 You, obviously, haven't spent much time talking with current unionized teachers in the US. I have. You have peers grading your quizes (so the teacher doesn't have to). There are handouts (that I've personally seen) that were "mimeographed", not copied on a printer, but mimeographed as they were done 30 years ago, telling me that this was a 30 year old lesson. It doesn't take much prep time to present 30 year old lessons, IMO.
 Teachers DON'T work 12 hour days. I drive by the parking lots of schools every day. The cars aren't there when I drive past in the morning and they aren't there when I drive past the schools on my way home.
 When you get to high school, many of the tests are done on computer-graded cards that are the "fill in the dot" variety.
 And all of this occurred in a "National Blue Ribbon Award" winning high school.

Teachers don't mark in schools if they can help it. In secondary school, college and university, there is a lot of 'behind the scenes' work. Lesson plans can't be re-run for 30 years in the UK. Science has progressed too much for that, history develops and changes too quickly, while English and similar subjects keep changing topic to stay with current trends. Pupils don't want to analyse the same books for decades; new books are often used.
 
 I have no idea how people can be using 'fill in the dot' tests much. In the UK, History, Classics, English and most humanities are essay subjects, while the sciences are far too complicated to use 'fill in the dots' tests. They don't want to test how good your brain is at being a sponge; they want to test intelligence.
 
 -Wez

Wez is correct, most teachers do a lot of their work at home. I know a fair few teachers and trainee teachers, and the rate of burnout from overwork in phenomenol. It may be different in the US but I'd be very surprised, given the additional problems the US has with gang violence and disrespect for education. I'm not suggesting you're lying, but maybe you're only seeing the bad things that are done, and assuming the worst. Maybe a 30 year old worksheet is being used as part of a lesson, but maybe that lesson has other, more recent, resources used as well. I'm also not sure what the problem is with using effective material just because it happens to be a few years old.

 I've seen all levels of professionalism amongst unionized teachers, but I can only report what I've seen with my own eyes. They don't put in 12 hour days, far from it. Teacher conferences aren't even held at night routinely any more. Most take place during school hours with the students being dismissed early. When they do have occasional conferences that run later, teachers are given comp time. Coaching, mentoring clubs, etc., are all paid for via overtime. Nothing is done out of the kindness of their hearts. (cavaet: I live in the NEA's strongest unionized area in the US, Detroit subs)

 Yeesh, if that's what it's like then you probably have a point, I'm just glad the unions over here have a rather more mature attitude. I'd be interested to hear the NEA's rationale for all this though. I know over here teachers are regularly working until midnight on weekdays on marking and preparation. Parent's Evenings (I presume this is the equivalent of your teacher conferences) are, as the name suggests, still held outside of school time, with no extra pay. Similarly extracurricular activities are all organised by teachers or parents volunteering their time, with no remuneration. It's also not uncommon for teachers to spend their own money on books and equipment for their class, if the school is short of cash.
